data.title: Congratulations Team Kenya, you're MEA leader in Road Safety!
data.message:
Our transporters Roy Hauliers has sustained its status as a 5-star transporter for 3 years,  making it the only transporter within the MEA region of LafargeHolcim to have the highest road safety rating. 

In 2018 Dakawaou Transporters (pictured receiving their certificate during the Annual Transporters Meeting) joined the 5-star league!

This makes Kenya the only country with 5-star transporters in the MEA region, now two, and a proud moment for us as we strive to maintain the highest standards in road safety! 

The rating of our transporters is part of LafargeHolcim road safety audit program and is awarded after a 5-Pillar audit conducted annually by a LafargeHolcim cross-functional team and validated by the Regional Head of Road Safety. During the audit actions are identified for the transporters to close within the year, with a follow up audit carried our to validate closure rate.

We have seen continuous improvement by our transporters year on year and we expect more entrants to the 5-star league in coming years. 

As our transporters improve we have also as a country continued to improve our general country rating year on year.
 
We call on you to continue availing yourselves for road patrols, audits, as well as sharing feedback on road behavior to support our transporters ratings and to get more from the lower ranks to join the 5-star rating. 

Congratulations once more Team Kenya!

data.title: We have two new products!
data.message:
PowerWhite is a white Portland cement that binds together aggregates (sand, ballast) in a concrete or mortar mix, while Poweraft is our unique offer to large projects that involves extremely rapid continuous supply of mass concrete volumes.

These new products are in line with Bamburi's vision which seeks to delight our customers with the widest range of products. 

PowerWhite is a Bamburi Cement product that can be used for a variety of construction and repair applications like creation of Terrazzo, provision of unique combination of shapes, sizes, textures & colour with the concrete, pattern versatility among many other uses. 

It  binds together aggregates (sand, ballast) in a concrete or mortar mix to create a more versatile and colourful finish to concrete surfaces. It is similar to ordinary grey Portland Cement in all aspects except for its high degree of whiteness. 

Poweraft on the other hand is a unique offer that involves extremely rapid continuous supply of mass concrete volumes to large projects. A product of Bamburi Special Products (BSP), it has been used in projects like the AVIC project and the National Olympic Committee of Kenya office block at Upper Hill.

data.title: Health Fact Sheet - CHIKUNGUNYA
data.message:
Chikungunya is a viral illness transmitted to humans by mosquitoes. It is characterized by acute onset of fever and severe aches in the joints.

Most people infected with Chikungunya virus will develop some symptoms, which will usually begin 3–7 days after being bitten by an infected mosquito.

The most common symptoms are:
	Fever and joint pain.
Other symptoms may include:
	Headache, 
	Muscle pain, 
	Joint swelling, or 
	Rash.

Chikungunya disease does not often result in death, but the symptoms can be severe and disabling.
	Most patients feel better within a week. 
	In some people, the joint pain may persist for months.
	People at risk for more severe disease include newborns infected around the time of birth, older adults (≥65 years), and people with medical conditions such as high blood pressure, diabetes, or heart disease.

Refer to the complete Health Fact Sheet about this disease circulated on 7th August 2018 on email from ke-communication.department@lafargeholcim.com

data.title: Priorities Under Focus for the Reminder of 2018
data.message:
These are the three priority areas under focus for the remainder of 2018, as per Message from the CCEO dated 3rd August 2018:

1.    Industrial performance
The industrial issues need to be solved quickly and everyone needs to ensure we deliver clinker production (and recover what we lost in H1), and improve clinker factor.

2.    TTAT and supply chain
It is not acceptable that a customer needs to wait 7 hours to be served and a clinker truck 4 hours to be off loaded. It is important to set the basics to ensure that any truck does not wait more than 2 hours to leave the plant. This will enable us to reduce transport costs and increase our sales.

3.    Cost savings
In a context where many costs have increased, we need to challenge and reduce all our costs, both industrial and SG&A. This will be implemented through a proactive negotiation from procurement and a Zero Based Budget approach for SG&A. 

Our focus will be on these three priorities, while ensuring that we continue to work in a safe environment. We were able to create success stories. It is still time to create other ones!

For the complete message, please refer to the Message from the CCEO circulated on 3rd August 2018 from ke-communication.department@lafargeholcim.com.

data.title: MOM Plant Launches Building Performance Program
data.message:
The graduate trainees and some of our supervisors  have been enrolled in the Regional Be Ready Program. 

The  face to face training is scheduled to take place in Mombasa Plant at the Plant School for the period of 30th September to 12th October 2018.  

We expect to have 8 participants from Kenya, 3 from Benin, 1 from Egypt, 3 from Ivory Coast, 3 from Algeria and 2 from Guinea. 

The launch was filled with words of wisdom from the MOM Plant Manager Mohamed Kharraki who went through a similar Learning and Development program known as CPDP. The program has been designed to lay the foundations for industrial excellence in LafargeHolcim.

The participants are expected to complete 34 assignments before the end of September and have already been issued with their workbooks. The Coaches have been provided with their Coaching guide  too! 

The purpose of the program is to offer a systematic perspective across Plant processes and functions, while instilling the mindset and behaviors at the core of the new company culture. 

It is a one year blended journey that provides induction in all manufacturing processes from Quarry to Lorry, Best Practices & Standards, Tools & Resources and Basic Managerial skills.

data.title: Transformation Journey - TTAT Actions Update
data.message:

> Project team has conducted brainstorming sessions on how to reduce TTAT < 2 hours and increase sales
> Detailed TTAT process mapping, analysis and opportunity identification completed
> Captures the direct input of all departments and Nairobi Plant Manager (17 persons)
> 47 main opportunities were registered to improve TTAT, by covering the:
      >> Sales Process
      >>Truck Inspection
      >> Order Assignment
      >> Yard Waiting time
      >> Loading time
      >> Overall process safety

In TTAT - Outbound:

> The following quick actions are enabling TTAT reduction so far:
       >> Overall awareness and sense of urgency improvement from Bamburi employees related to TTAT
      >> Fast line set-up for 10T trucks
      >> Weighbridge reliability improvement
      >> Daily delay analysis and corrective actions
     >> Improved Inspection process
     >>Overall dispatch productivity improvement

> Compared to the base of 8 hours the reduction of turnaround time has been positive and encouraging
> The total TTAT has been reduced by 43% in average for the last 6 weeks.
>Important actions related to Maintenance, loading organization, bag quality, housekeeping & parking signalization, supervisory routines, customer service process and sales are still to be completed.

data.title: Do You Know the Energy Isolation Job Specific Procedures?
data.message:
Before any work on a PES (Potentially Energized System), job specific procedures must be available and must include:

1. Identification of:
> all sources and types of energy
> all isolation points for each energy source
> energy isolation device for each isolation point and 
> the correct sequence of isolation

2. Method to:
> shut down, deactivate, isolate, block and secure the PESs
> release stored and residual energy
> place and transfer Lock-Out/Tag-Out devices
> confirm the effectiveness of Lock-Out devices and other energy control measures (Test-Out)
> remove Lock-Out/Tag-Out devices
> restore the energy after the task

3. Competency, authorization and supervision to carry out the procedure. 

Note: Treat all PESs as energized (live) until a Test-Out confirms otherwise. 

Read the full details in the Energy Isolation  Standard. Click on this link for the Visual Guide  https://m-bamburi.com/uploads/newsletters/5bb2072325c4e.pdf

data.title: Today is Healthy Thursday! Let's Talk About Your Heart
data.message:
What's Your Promise, For Your Heart?

Did you know?
 Each day, your heart beats around 100,000 times.
 Your heart pumps about five litres of blood around your body.
 The heart is approximately the size of your fist
 The strongest muscle in your body is the heart.
 Your heart started beating about 3 weeks after you were conceived.
 If you live to be 70 years, your heart will have beaten 2 and ½ billion times. 

Make a promise... "for my heart, for your heart, for all our hearts"  

"I promise as an individual to cook and eat more healthily, to do more exercise and encourage my children and other relatives to be more active, to say no to smoking and help my loved ones to stop." 

Make a promise today!  For your Heart.

data.title: How Do I as an Employee Contribute to Cost Leadership?
data.message:
Cost Leadership remains a key focus area for our business.

Important points to take note of:

1. We are the drivers of every cost the business incurs (mainly through making the decision to purchase...)
2. Whenever incurring these costs therefore let us ask ourselves:
o	Are we getting the right quality and price - how are we sourcing?
o	Are we sourcing it from the right place?
o	Is what I am procuring really adding value to the business, or is it just a 'good to have'?
o	Can I work innovatively to reduce this cost, or even avoid it? 
o	Can I re-evaluate the way I work and avoid buying things just because 'it's always been done?'
o	If I was buying this item or service for personal use, would this be the price I'd expect? Does it make sense to me?

Let us all own the cost leadership mindset for our success!

data.title: Good Practice Sharing - Making Customers Happy with Digital Solutions in Morocco
data.message:
“Are you happy?” Check out how our colleagues are making customers happy with digital solutions in Morocco. https://connect.lafargeholcim.com/global/are-you-happy

With an average of 250,000 customers trucks picking up around 7 million tons every year, LafargeHolcim aims to please. The industrial, logistics and digital teams are working together to identify solutions to improve customer experience within our plants. In Morocco, they’re implementing two exciting digital initiatives that improve the experience of customers and employees.

Customer truck information in real time

The primary goal of the digital solution “Massary” is to reduce the amount of time our trucks are parked and loading within the plants. But it does more. It provides real time, transparent queue management, while also controlling for the accuracy of products provided. “The tool tracks every truck from the moment they park until they exit the factory,” says Lamia Joundy, Digital Operations Manager. “We use RFID badges provided to each driver when they arrive to do the tracking.”

The solution is operational in Meknes plant and will be rolled out to all other sites in the country by the beginning of 2019. “We’re excited by the prospects of this tool after its success in Meknes,” says Idriss Elasri, Procurement, Logistics and Marketing Director.

Hearing directly from the customer

They didn’t stop with Massary. Idriss added, “We wanted to further understand our drivers’ needs in order to continue improving their experience with and perception of LafargeHolcim Morocco, so we developed an application for just this purpose.”

With 3JBKOUMLHAL (“Are you happy?” or “Did you like it?” in Arabic) every driver now has the possibility to rank their experience. “We use a tablet for the drivers,” explains Ghita Mouttaqi-Allah, Digital Customer Manager, “which allows us to measure the impact of our processes on customer satisfaction – in real time.” The results have led to quick wins, but also more ambitious improvements in operations. Following a test phase at the Bouskoura and Settat plants, 3JBKOUMLHAL will also be rolled out at the beginning of 2019.

data.title: Good Practice Sharing - Drones: changing how we operate our plants
data.message:
In this Group case study sharing, find out how drones will help save lives, cut costs and accelerate growth.

Industry 4.0, and new process and engineering technologies are two key areas to drive the Simplification & Performance value driver of Strategy 2022 - “Building for Growth”. Both of them open up new avenues for growth and innovation, and help accelerate digitization across our industrial sites. 

Today, drones are readily used at our plants and are one of the innovations of Industry 4.0 where we are most advanced. This innovation is radically and rapidly changing the way we work, from protecting our employees and increasing our competitiveness, to achieving cost savings and creating efficiencies for running industrial operations. The potential for future usage of drones is huge. 

A recent report by Goldman Sachs* predicts that the commercial sector represents the biggest growth opportunity for drone technologies. Investments of USD 13 billion are expected in the construction industry alone by 2022. While CIP & PME have been following up on using drones in our industrial sites - from site inspections to surveys and stockpiling - the Group has only scratched the surface of what can be done with airborne drones and how this technology will change the way we work.

“Silo cleaning is a great example for the benefits obtained across Health & Safety, cost savings and improved productivity when using drones,” explains Laurent Seyler, Head of New Technologies for CIP & PME. “First, inspecting and cleaning cement silos is a high-exposure task where we’ve unfortunately experienced fatalities in the past. In the future, we will be able to avoid sending people to inspect and clean silos or any other confined space and instead use drones,” he adds.  

Predictive maintenance is another key area where drones are making operations more efficient. With drones, inspections can occur at higher frequency and issues can be detected remotely through real-time imagery or non-destructive analysis before they arise. This saves time and money associated with costly repairs. 

Finally, where mapping, surveillance and measurement of raw materials stored in the open and requiring blast design used to be costly, the use of drones has cut this spend to a fraction of earlier levels. Says Laurent: “Any way you look at it, drones are helping us to create operational excellence and greatly benefit our business.”

Creating competitiveness and the Plant of Tomorrow

“As Drone technology continues to evolve, I believe that we will see it used in many ways as we create ‘The Plants of Tomorrow’,” adds Laurent. As drones collect vast amounts of data, it will be possible to analyze and utilize the data to prepare volume calculations, create engineering designs and create 3-D in Building Information Models (BIM) using virtual reality. “This means that we will not only become more efficient in how we run our sites, reinvent processes and increase productivity, we will also create new employment opportunities at our sites for skilled people who can help turn data into actionable insights.”

Laurent Seyler is the Head of New Technologies for CIP and PME. His team is charged with driving disruptive change at our plants via process innovation and industry 4.0. From drones, robotics, all the way to innovative solutions that reduce C02 emissions as well as cost, this newly-formed team in Holderbank is tasked with enabling, equipping and providing best practice expertise to plant teams around the world on how to future-proof their manufacturing sites. To learn more about CIP & PME, visit the team’s Connect site.

Source: Goldman Sachs report.
